11:09 am
PM

Some Spangel

PM

The move in iron ore is thought to follow further rises in property prices in China.
Demand continues to increase in the big cities but weak property price growth is seen in smaller cities though growth is still better than negative returns.
Traders and steel producers generally get ready to ramp up production into Q2 following the Chinese New Year as the weather warms and policy makers confirm plans for the year.
We believe the closure of inefficient and polluting steel plants in China is good for seaborne iron ore prices and for import volumes of better quality Australian and Brazalian iron ore.
The loss of as much as 100mtpa of iron ore production in Brazil due to a tightening of the licensing regime in Brazil following the massive Samarco tailings disaster may also help prices higher.

PM

(Tech has defeated Neil btw. Auto password expiry, which makes passwords unusable for anyone who comes into the FT occasionally. grrrr...)

11:12 am
PM

Actually, Investec got a thorough run thru on iron ore

PM

(Blimey -- welcome back fjp73. Thought you'd gone the way of Bryce.)

PM

With low cost iron ore supply continuing to rise we consider which
producers are still likely to be required given changing demand from the
Chinese steel industry. We consider which equities offer best value for their
iron ore exposures and suggest that amongst the UK listed stocks Ferrexpo
shows the best relative value upside while Anglo shows least. RIO and BHP
currently trade at fair value with reference to their iron ore exposures.

11:13 am
PM

Global iron ore markets are oversupplied: Given our estimated cumulative
supply surplus of 332Mt over the past fifteen years, and allowing for a further
232Mt of planned added low cost capacity we estimate that without any capacity
closures iron ore demand must grow at a rate of 3.2% per annum over the next
ten years in order to balance supply. We see this growth rate as highly unlikely
given the slowdown in Chinese steel demand.

PM

We think rationalisation of supply is inevitable: Recently added capacity has
generally lower production costs than many current producers and is therefore
unlikely to be mothballed. In our view, this growth in supply at a time when
demand is structurally weak means displacement and rationalisation of much
existing iron ore supply could occur.

PM

EBITDA/t curve considered: We have constructed an EBITDA/t curve
(preferred approach to traditional cost curve analysis) and conclude it is unlikely
that iron ore supply from South African listed Anglo, ARM, KIO and BHP will be
displaced. This remains the case even if zero iron ore demand growth is
assumed over ten years. Under an assumption of zero demand growth we
believe 734Mt will need to be closed over the next decade (resulting in a net
402Mt after removal of the cumulative surplus of 332Mt) in order to bring supply
and demand into balance.

11:13 am
PM

EV/t vs. EBITDA/t used to determine best value: We consider a regression of
EV/t versus EBITDA/t for listed global peers to determine which companies offer
the best relative value for exposure to the iron ore market. Our analysis shows
the market tends to reward greater profitability (EBITDA/tonne iron ore) with a
higher valuation (EV/tonne iron ore).

PM

RIO and BHP fair value: For the UK listed miners Ferrexpo shows the best
relative value upside, on an unrisked basis, while Anglo shows the least. Rio
Tinto and BHP Billiton are shown to be at fair value at best and in some
scenarios an expensive way to gain exposure to iron ore.

PM

Former Deutsche traders

PM

The Serious Fraud Office said it had obtained European arrest warrants for five suspects who have been charged in its investigation into Euribor manipulation.

Four of the men are in Germany and one is in France, James Waddington QC said at a hearing at Southwark Crown Court on Friday, reports Lindsay Fortado.

They are Andreas Hauschild, Joerg Vogt, Ardalan Gharagozlou and Kai-Uwe Kappauf, all formerly at Deutsche Bank, and Stephane Esper, a former trader at Societe Generale.

The men are scheduled to stand trial in London in September next year along with six others from Deutsche and Barclays.

PM

That's on Fast FT

http://on.ft.com/1Wvptgq

undefined
PM

fjp -- Marc Elliott from Investec and team

11:18 am
PM

Correction: Hunter Hillcoat and team

PM

Elliott's on Anglo American

PM

Which he doesnt like

11:18 am
PM

Anglo American’s latest business plan to focus on copper, PGMs and
Diamonds is a reversal on its previous diversified strategy. The necessity of
fixing the balance sheet appears to be the overriding driver. We argue that
selling non-core assets for US$3-4bn removes a US$2bnpa contribution of
EBITDA by 2020 and is value neutral to shareholders, implying a spin-out
could be a more attractive option. Necessity is the mother of invention. SELL

PM

No growth and no yield, forever

PM

We believe management’s proposal to cut the business to three core divisions
is a reflection of the challenges the company faces in order to better manage
downside risk from commodity prices. Fixing the currently over-geared balance
sheet will take time given the “disincentive pricing” commodity price regime we
forecast - but should be achievable by 2020. As a result, for now, we believe
Anglo American (‘Anglo’) presents limited equity appeal - given no growth and
no yield for the foreseeable future.

11:19 am
PM

The shift out of bulk commodities appears a sensible decision in our view;
however we think the disposal strategy to raise US$3-4bn presents limited
value to equity holders. The company appears, for now, not to be in a position
to emulate BHPs action of exiting non-core assets via spinning out a business,
such as South 32, thereby removing optionality for shareholders.
 In our view, the recent near 200% share price rally gave the company a
chance to raise new equity without incurring excess dilution. However,
management has frequently stated that a rights issue is not necessary given
‘sufficient liquidity’. Looking ahead, the company’s gearing target of net
debt/EBITDA of 2x is commensurate with regaining an investment grade rating
in order to facilitate the renewal of its core revolving credit facility in 2020.
 We have updated our forecasts to reflect further cost cutting measures and the
updated balance sheet position. Our SoTP includes market values for listed
subsidiaries Amplats and Exxaro - which have both rallied strongly this year.
We maintain a 20% discount for ongoing balance sheet risk and reset our TP
at 310p. We retain our Sell recommendation.

PM

Nevertheless...

Berkeley Group Holdings PLC (BKG:LSE): Last: 3,151, down 106 (-3.25%), High: 3,250, Low: 3,124, Volume: 660.39k

Let me get Robin Hardy of Shore to run thru

11:24 am
PM

A generally positive IMS that confirms the overall delivery of profits across this and the next two financial years will still be around £2bn in aggregate. There has never been any indication of how this £2bn would be split but there is an indication that for FY2016 that PBT is likely to be above £500m against consensus £470m and our £451m. Frankly, the split between the three years is not really significant especially as next year and in FY2018 there is going to be a major jump up to, or above, £750m. These are likely to be peak profit levels from the sell through of the excellent positioning the group secured in the prime central London market some years back but that party is very much over now and the real question here is what profile will Berkeley have once London is traded out and what will the underlying level of profits be? It is clear that Berkeley is repositioning for a very different business profile buying sites for flats in outer London boroughs and increasingly it would appear more sites for mainstream family housing with sites such as Ascot or Winchester.

PM

We would still expect the group to have a bias towards the more expensive end of the market, and these locations support that, and good margins can be made but the super-normal margins that London has produced and the very rapid pace of sales is likely to be very hard to repeat. However, we are confident that Berkeley should be capable of maintaining a level of profit of at least the £500m or so that it should deliver this year in the longer term and that its record argues still for a material premium rating over the peer group. This still supports a fair value of around £35 per share and having recently dropped below £30 there is currently some value here, although the recent rally has already redeemed a great deal of this. The news that Berkeley is largely shrugging off the perceived problems in the prime central London market must be seen as a positive but, to be honest, this should not be a surprise to anyone – it was never likely to get caught out and problems with unsold homes in London is likely to be a problem for newer players who came much later into the London market. We stay at HOLD for now but this is still a business we like very much and we could easily be proved too cautious on the profitability the new model will produce. The shares are likely to rally today with the upper end guidance and could easily pass our fair value of 3525p in the next couple of days.

PM

Well no, the stock hasn't rallied today

11:25 am
PM

The guys at Aviate remain cautious on this

PM

Brexit uncertainty

PM

An IMS from Berkeley Group this morning gives some comfort that the business, as for its underlying asset of London land/property, remains in good health. The dividend return programme remains on target for a £1/share in September and the expected April y/e cash of £100m leaves the group with flexibility over future land expenditures. Current UK referendum fears, and rising transaction taxes on higher cost properties, have pushed reservations down around 4% on last year, but the firm says that underlying demand remains strong and actual sales on

£2m properties are in line with last year at 62 sales since the end of October, i.e. during fiscal 2H16. The firm's prosperity comes from the robust London and South of England housing market, where it has focused its operations. While a perceived strength for some, there is certainly some uncertainty as to how Brexit might play out for them, which is why we suggested taking profits in the name recently. Great company with fabulous divididend no doubt, but with outcome uncertaity such as this, we feel safer stepping aside until an answer becomes clear.

11:29 am
undefined
PM

Macro interlude

PM

Gavekal Research -- often well worth a read

11:31 am
PM

This is from Charles Gave

PM

Dan pinged it over earlier

PM

Interesting thinking....

11:31 am
PM

We Are Killing The Wrong Pig — by Charles Gave

PM

Lord Keynes, who was a lot smarter than most Keynesians, argued strongly in favor of the euthanasia of the rentier. I see the logic. The rentier has almost by definition a huge preference for liquidity (to use the Keynesian terminology), which leads automatically to a very low velocity of money, and from there to recession. So the idea is to force the rentier into a lower preference for liquidity, which should lead to a higher velocity of money. And if the velocity of money goes up, the problem of a contracting economy is solved.

PM

t’s an idea enthusiastically embraced by policymakers today. The trouble is that the ignoramuses who manage our central banks and tax systems are still using the definition of the rentier which prevailed 80 years ago when Keynes published The General Theory of Employment, Interest and Money. So, our policymakers are busy taxing to death poor retirees and their pension funds—retirees who spent a lifetime scrimping and saving in the hope they would accumulate a small pot of money to ensure their last years on this earth would not be too uncomfortable.

11:32 am
PM

Let’s go back to a solid principle: as a rule, a saver should maintain a weighting of bonds in his portfolio equal to 100 minus his age. So if he is 60 years old, he should have 60% of his savings in bonds (which equate to a low velocity of money), and no more than 40% in equities. If the effect of official policy is to reduce the returns on the portion of his portfolio held in bonds, then our saver will have to increase his savings rate. As a result the velocity of money will collapse. Sure enough, that is exactly what we see happening today, to the immense surprise of the over-educated ignoramuses running the show.

Keynes may well have been right about the desirability of euthanizing the rentier, but policymakers have failed to realize who the real rentier is today.

PM

Watching the endless columns of the Soviet Red Army march past during the allies’ victory parade in Berlin in 1945, Winston Churchill is said to have turned to an aide and muttered, “I am afraid we killed the wrong pig.”

That is exactly what the authorities are doing today: killing the wrong pig. The real rentiers of today are notordinary bond-holders saving for their retirement, but the likes of Apple, Microsoft and Google—multinational corporations who together hold trillions of US dollars in cash in offshore tax heavens, and who have absolutely no idea what to do with these sums.

PM

The solution is to pass legislation stipulating that companies can distribute dividends to shareholders free of tax, but that earnings retained as cash will be taxed at 100%. If such a law were to be passed, I have zero doubt that distributing corporate cash to its ultimate owners via dividends rather than hoarding it indefinitely for no purpose, would prove admirably effective in pushing the velocity of money sharply higher.

If a company needs to invest, it can raise the money through a rights issue, and the market will judge whether or not the proposed investment is a good idea. That will prevent the chief executive officer from continuing to invest the company’s positive cash flows in activities with a miserable return, simply because those are the businesses that he knows.

11:32 am
PM

Of course, interest payments by companies should be made no longer tax-deductible, which should put a stop to the deplorable financial engineering indulged in over recent years by CEOs anxious to get their stock options vested.

The more I think about it, the more I am convinced that Keynes may really have been on to something. Let’s not tax yesterday’s rentiers, as we are doing today. That cannot work, is not working, and is demonstrably unfair. Instead, let’s force the rentiers of today to give their money back to its legitimate owners. That could, and should, work.

PM

/ends

undefined

PM

PM

PM

PM

http://www.ft.com/...n=uk#axzz439cIt3oe

11:35 am
PM

And RBS

PM

High quality global journalism requires investment. Please share this article with others using the link below, do not cut & paste the article. See our Ts&Cs and Copyright Policy for more detail. Email ftsales.support@ft.com to buy additional rights. http://www.ft.com/...html#ixzz43FmTXZe4

The kind of cross-looking woman often shown on the homepage of the Ofcom website is not Sharon White, but the chief executive shares such irritation. The telecoms regulator is not happy at the prospect of O2 disappearing into Li Ka-shing’s global empire, reducing the premier league of UK mobile providers from four to three.
This week she published the snappily-entitled “cross-country econometric analysis of the effect of disruptive firms on mobile pricing”. After studying conditions in 25 countries, this confirms what any fool knows, that disruptive firms do indeed disrupt, while more competition means lower prices — around a fifth lower with four operators rather than three, provided one of them is disruptive.

PM

Do have a read

11:37 am
Imagination Technologies Group PLC (IMG:LSE): Last: 186.00, up 1.25 (+0.68%), High: 190.75, Low: 185.00, Volume: 1.67m
PM

Achal Sultania of Credit Suisse is leery

PM

Cost cutting provides temporary relief, key
issue remains lack of sales growth

11:38 am
PM

While edging up the CS price target

PM

Increasing estimates and TP, reiterate UP. Post increased cost savings
program along with recent move in GBP/USD (7% sales tailwind due to FX move
from 1.52 to 1.42), we increase our EBIT estimates for IMG (incl. PURE business
which is up for sale) from £8.3mn/£10.0mn in FY17/FY18 to £25.1mn/£20.4mn.
This now drives EPS of 7.00p/5.65p respectively (vs. 2.30p/2.80p previously). As
such, we raise our TP to 130p (vs. 85p previously). However, given our structural
concerns in both its core GPU/CPU businesses (continued share loss in GPU
and limited traction with MIPS in CPU), we reiterate UP rating

PM

Another cost cutting program, £27.5mn in total now. IMG first announced
cost cutting on 8
th Feb where it planned £15mn savings in FY17 (this also
involved 150 employees, of which 100 were related to PURE and rest 50 related
to overheads). In addition, IMG now has announced additional £12.5mn cost
savings to be delivered in full in FY17 (£10mn in personnel costs impacting 200
employees and £2.5mn costs linked to marketing and property). This implies total
headcount reduction of 350, which is 21% of FY15 headcount of 1,652. The
average payroll cost (all in) of an IMG employee was £58k in FY15, so reduction
of 350 employees implies £20mn payroll savings. Cash cost relating to these
restructuring plans is expected to be £5mn and will be funded from current cash
position (IMG had £8mn in gross cash and £35mn in net debt as of 1HFY16)

11:38 am
PM

Key concerns around lack of growth in GPU. IMG's graphics shipments
continue to see pressures where its units peaked at 535mn in FY13, and we now
expect 470mn/455mn in FY17/FY18 despite growth in the smartphone market.
We believe that IMG's share at MTEK is still at ~25% (mainly at the high end),
which we see as coming down contrary to company's expectations given MTEK's
recent high end portfolio of chips (Helio X20, X25, P10, P20) all now using ARM's
Mali graphics. As a result, in spite of FX tailwinds, we see IMG's revenues (incl.
PURE) down from £155mn in FY16 to £150mn in FY17

PM

TP of 130p, reiterate UP as shares expensive even excluding PURE losses.
We model EPS of 7.00p/5.65p (with PURE) in FY17/FY18, which goes up to
7.50p/6.45p if we exclude PURE losses. We value IMG on 20x FY3 PE of 6.50p
(in-line with last 3 years avg.) which drives our new TP of 130p. This also implies
EV/sales of 3.0x (vs. last avg. of 2.8x since 2013).

PM

Singer are buyers

11:39 am
PM

Imagination announced a further £12.5m of cost savings yesterday. This is on top of the £15m of savings announced in February. Importantly the three core businesses, PowerVR, MIPS and Ensigma, will be unaffected by the cuts, with investment in PowerVR actually increasing. We previously outlined a scenario involving £8.5m of additional cost savings, which resulted in us increasing our TP to 191p. Yesterday’s announcement went further, driving larger upgrades than we had anticipated. We upgrade our adj. PBT forecasts by 114% and 53% in FY’17 and FY’18 respectively and increase our DCF derived TP to 207p. We continue to believe that Imagination is a highly attractive asset which, at the current level, is vulnerable to a takeover. Buy.

undefined
PM

Boncoeur -- yeah, ok

11:42 am
PM

I'd share some traditional 'macro' on the ECB

PM

But Merrill are just making me go thru a new registration process...

PM

And the end result...

11:43 am
PM

Is really not worth the effort....

PM

We have seen it in the past. When the ECB announced the government bond buying program, inflows accelerated into the asset class. With the help of the ECB, credit flows broke free from a long period of outflows. Last week's positive inflow into high-grade and high-yield funds was the third consecutive and the biggest in 53 weeks.

This considerable shift in momentum was mainly thanks to a decisive shift in high grade. The asset class recorded its first inflow in ten weeks and the biggest for more than a year. High yield funds enjoyed another - the fourth in a row - week of inflows.

Elsewhere in fixed income, government bond funds recorded another outflow during the previous week.

Money market fund flows were also in the negative territory, recording a fourth consecutive outflow - the longest streak since March '15.

To the contrary outflows continued from equity funds. The asset class has suffered outflows for the last six weeks, which now sum up to $15bn. This is the longest period of outflows seen in equities since October '14.

Commodity fund flows remained positive for the eleventh week in a row. This reflects inflows particularly into gold funds.

Inflows into EM debt funds reflected the relief rally in EM FX. Flows to the EM debt funds are on their fourth positive week.

undefined
11:45 am
PM

Here's something a bit different...

PM

From Michael Briest at UBS

PM

We partnered with UBS Evidence Lab to collect and analyse the feedback of nearly 40k active employees on Glassdoor. The analysis covered nearly 50 software companies to gauge the relationship between employee satisfaction and shareholder returns.

11:46 am
PM

Internal and external perceptions of leadership quality seem to be shared
We partnered with UBS Evidence Lab to collect and analyse the feedback of nearly 40k
active employees on Glassdoor. The analysis covered nearly 50 software companies to
gauge the relationship between employee satisfaction and shareholder returns. The
high correlation (95-96%) between the perception of the CEO and senior management
and the overall score awarded to an employer, led us to focus on leadership credentials
and here we found evidence that those companies seeing the greatest improvement in
internal reviews of leadership quality (CEO satisfaction), also tended to deliver outsized
shareholder returns: The ten software companies that had the highest four-year
improvement in CEO approval (through the end of 2015) enjoyed an average share
price return of 121%. The bottom ten returned 35%. Looking at the ten companies
with the greatest y/y improvement in Glassdoor CEO ratings in 2015, we have a Buy on
Microsoft. Of the ten with the greatest fall, we are sellers of Sage and Temenos.

PM

Buy Microsoft? Really?

PM

Are founders better than "professional" managers as leaders? Not necessarily
Software is a fast-paced sector and success can come quickly for the right company.
Often, founders are the CEO at the point of listing the business but we think it is a
commonly-held perception that entrepreneurs can be ill-equipped to take a business
from growth into maturity and "professional" managers are best suited for the latter
stages of a company's development. Around a quarter of our Software sample was still
led by the founder, and averaged a 3.86 satisfaction rating, compared with 3.58 for
these run by external leadership. Saying that, the highest-scoring company overall (Palo
Alto Networks) is not run founder-led, while Microstrategy, the lowest-scoring, is.

11:47 am
PM

Leadership change can have dramatic effects on equity performance
Satya Nadella's appointment as CEO at Microsoft coincided with improving leadership
ratings and an improving rating for the shares, showing that founders do not have a
monopoly on success. As interesting, arguably, is the decline in employee satisfaction at
Tibco and Informatica after (founder) CEO change at the culmination of a go-private
transaction. While a go-private transaction might reasonably be expected to impact
employee satisfaction we note that Compuware and Misys actually saw improving
Glassdoor scores after going private and seeing (non-founder) leadership change.

PM

PM

Cloud-babies?

PM

PM

11:59 am
PM

In fact they are worried about EM exposure, while upgrading the likes of Lloyds

PM

In a lower-for-longer world where monetary policy easing depresses asset
yields, we expect stocks with attractive dividend yields to outperform. With the
SX7P 2016E consensus dividend yield at 5.1% vs the SXXP at 3.7%, the banks
sector is among the top dividend-yielding sectors in Europe. Regulatory risks
have eased in recent months as policymakers have avoided tightening capital
requirements as the economic trends have weakened. Recession concerns
should be allayed by the ECB’s actions last week. Lower rates for longer also
implies lower cost of risk for longer. Once the market confirms the recent
weakness in economic data as a slowdown rather than recession, its confidence
in the ability of banks to pay the estimated dividend yield will grow further. Our
top picks are some of the highest yielding stocks in the sector, with a robust and
improving capital position yielding c6.9% in 2016 on our estimates.

PM

Santander, Standard Chartered, HSBC top underweights
Emerging market (EM) exposed banks continue to face a number of
headwinds. Our house view is that China GDP growth will be 5.8% in 2016,
falling further to 5.6% in 2017 (consensus at 6.5% for 2016 and 6.2% for
2017). Similarly, we are below consensus for Asia ex-Japan GDP growth. We
expect the Fed to keep tightening monetary policy, while we expect EM-Asia to
continue easing policy, which could create further forex headwinds. With the
build-up of credit in Asia over the past decade now looking to unwind, we
expect a credit cycle in Asia to strengthen over the coming years. In this
context we downgrade Standard Chartered (STAN) and HSBC to Reduce
(from Neutral), with Santander (SAN) already on a Reduce rating.

12:00 pm
PM

Expecting capital markets revenues to fall 7% y-o-y
With Barclays turning from an investment banking (IB) shrink story into an IB
recovery story, we are turning more cautious on the group and downgrade it to
Neutral. We think fixed income, equity and IBD fee pools could be down 7%, 4%
and 10%, respectively, vs 2015. Although we have also cut estimates for CS
Group and Deutsche Bank (DBK), we still see value in the mix of the former and
deep value of the latter.

PM

Margin outlook challenging in a negative rate world
In a negative interest rate world, banking systems that can re-price asset
margins to offset liability margin pressures can maintain profitability. For much
of continental Europe margins remain a headwind. We show that the TLTRO-2
can improve margins by c7-16bp, but it is unlikely to offset the broader margin
pressures seen in the eurozone. Credit growth is unlikely to much exceed
nominal GDP as indicated by ECB President, Mario Draghi, who highlights that
current policy is “inducing people to reduce debt, not to increase it”.

PM

That'll do

1:30 JCB Triumph Hurdle. ZUBAYR ex-French flat, successful hurdles start at Kempton 4/1 W. And small EW on LEONCAVALLO unseated here last time but won 1st 5 over hurdles hopefully freshened up 16/1 EW.

2:10 Handicap Hurdle - 26 runners and hope mine will stay upright. GREAT FIELD 8/1 EW ex french 2-2 hurdles, last time out winner after 521 day break. JOHN CONSTABLE useful flat stayer 2-3 in hurdles, dry ground will suit 14/1 EW

2:50 Albert Bartlett Novice Hurdle 3miles. Wide open vexing contest, but BARTERS HILL 3-3 hurdles including this course & distance sets the standard 4/1 W. CHAMPERS ON ICE on the board all 4 hurdle starts, 2 wins one here, hoping stop-up to 3 miles suits, nice EW odds 33/1 (No special offers here - generally 1/4 odds 3 places except Paddy goes 4 places but 1/5th and stingy Hills 3 places 1/5th - they must be hurting!).

3:30 Timico Gold Cup. Great depth this year. Could be O’Leary’s day - his DON COSSACK would have won the KingG but for falling 2 out. Beaten that day by the resurgent CUE CARD going for the £1m bonus today and a ‘staying double’ for Colin Tizzard. But if they give the handsome grey SMAD PLACE a soft lead he could surprise them all. So DON COSSACK 11/4 W; CUE CARD 4/1 W - (leave you to make your pick) and I’m ante-post EW 12/1 SMAD PLACE.

PM

4:10 The Foxhunters Chase and if a certain lady wins today surely be renamed The Pendleton. But don’t think Pacha Du Polda will stay. PAINT THE CLOUDS 6/1 W - third in this last year and smooth winner last run. And one of my old favs returns to Rules after 3 years but has won last twice in the Points - CHAPOTURGEON 33/1 tiny EW. (1/4 4 places).

4:50 Handicap Hurdle Conditional jockeys. Bet 365 paying 5 places EW so have a couple longish odds - FLYING ANGEL 14/1 EW won Sandown last week, hope not too soon again. MONTDRAGON lightly raced and 2-3 this season. 20/1 EW.

5:10 Grand Annual the finale & loads of big prices and I’ve saved my “completely off the wall” pick till now - SURF AND TURF back after a break and similarly won big Aintree handicap last year & at 80/1 EW what’s not to like?!!
But more sensibly - DANDRIDGE 12/1 EW - improved chaser but up 12lbs for last win, Davy Russell rides.

That’s all and hope we can get at least one reasonable result. Cheers!
